conversation.content: Um, excuse me, I think that's, well, actually my reserved cage—I've got the, you know, 3:30 slot?
Oh really? Because I'm, uh, pretty sure I booked this [condescending] exact cage for three-thirty, so maybe you want to, like, check your confirmation again?
Look, here's my receipt on my phone—cage seven, Tuesday, 3:30 PM.
Wait, that says Tuesday the fifteenth... today's Tuesday the twenty-second, my friend. You're exactly one week late to your reservation.
Oh my God, are you serious right now?
Hey, no worries though—I mean, the cage next to us is, err, completely empty and honestly, I could use someone to, you know, help me calibrate this new bat I just bought.
You want me to, um, help you [confused] calibrate a bat? What does that, like, even mean exactly?
Well, basically, I need to see if the, uh, weight distribution feels right when I'm, you know, actually swinging at different speeds—it's kind of a whole process.
That sounds unnecessarily complicated for hitting a ball.
Says the person who showed up a week late to their own reservation! But seriously, I'm training for the company softball championship next month.
Your company has a softball championship?
Oh absolutely—TechNova takes their, umm, recreational sports way too seriously, like, we've got jerseys, professional umpires, and honestly, the CEO personally hands out the trophy.
That's, well, either really cool or, I guess, completely insane—I can't, sort of, decide which.
It's definitely both! Last year someone, er, got a [cheerful] promotion right after hitting a grand slam, so now everyone thinks, you know, sports performance affects career trajectories.
No way! Did they [very excited] really get promoted because of softball?!
Well, correlation doesn't imply [overly polite] causation, of course, but the timing was rather suspiciously perfect, wouldn't you say?
I played division two [confidently] college ball—maybe your company is hiring?
Division two? Okay now I'm, like, actually impressed—what position did you, um, play, and more importantly, how's your, er, batting average these days?
Shortstop, career average .312, but I haven't played competitively in three years.
Three years is nothing! Muscle memory is, uhh, forever—grab a helmet and let's, actually, see if you've still [slurring] got it, because honestly, we desperately need a decent shortstop.
